clinical_study.brief_title: Active Videogames Against Obesity in Children
clinical_study.official_title: Active Video Games Against Obesity and Sedentarism in Children Between 9 and 11 Years Old: a Disruptive Proposal

brief_summary.textblock:
Active video games are presented as an exercise option for children with little interest in traditional sports. The main objectives of this study are:
1. To evaluate the effects of an active video game program on cardiometabolic risk in overweight/obese children
2. to identify the effect of this intervention on physical fitness
3. to study possible changes in the sedentary lifestyles of children after the exercise program.
This is a randomized crossover study, with 2 intervention periods of 9 months each, and a 3-month period of washing. Ninetytwo children between 9 and 11 years old who are overweight or obese will be included and randomly assigned to one of the 2 homogeneous groups (control-intervention). Both groups will receive education in healthy lifestyles, and the intervention group will also follow a physical exercise program with active video games (3-4 days/week). The sessions will last between 30 and 45 minutes and will include different moderate-vigorous aerobic activities and muscular strength exercises. Body composition, physical fitness, levels of leptin, adiponectin and visfatin, lipid and ferric profiles, and markers of inflammation and metabolic risk such as insulin resistance, TNF-α, CRP, ALT, AST, gamma-GT and IL-6will be measured before and after the intervention. In addition, dietary habits (24h recalls), physical activity (accelerometers), blood pressure, waist and neck circumference, and pubertal development will be also assessed.

detailed_description.textblock:
Childhood obesity is one of the main problems in developed societies, and entails enormous expenditure for the National Health System. In addition, childhood obesity is strongly associated with adult obesity and with all types of cardiovascular and metabolic pathologies. Physical exercise has been shown to be the great non-pharmacological enemy of both childhood and adult obesity, however sport practice and adherence to it is not easy in the overweight/obese population. In this context, active video games are presented as an exercise option for children with little interest in traditional sports. The main objectives of this study are: (1) To evaluate the effects of an active video game program on cardiometabolic risk in overweight/obese children; (2) to identify the effect of this intervention on physical fitness and (3) to study possible changes in the sedentary lifestyles of children after the exercise program.

Ninetytwo children between 9 and 11 years old who are overweight or obese will be included and randomly assigned to one of the 2 homogeneous groups (control-intervention). Both groups will receive education in healthy lifestyles, and the intervention group will also follow a physical exercise program with active video games (3-4 days/week). In addition, dietary habits (24h recalls), physical activity (accelerometers), blood pressure, waist and neck circumference, and pubertal development will be also assessed.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in fat mass during 6 months evaluated by Dual energy X-ray absorptiometry
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline in fat mass at 6 months
primary_outcome.description: Fat mass is measured by dual X-ray photon absorptiometry (DXA) using the software and pediatric reference values (Hologic Explorer, Hologic Corp., Software Latest Version, Waltham, MA).

primary_outcome.measure: Change in size during 6 months evaluated by a height rod to the nearest 0.1 cm (SECA 225, SECA, Hamburg, Germany).
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline in size at 6 months
primary_outcome.description: Height is measured with a height rod to the nearest 0.1 cm (SECA 225, SECA, Hamburg, Germany),

primary_outcome.measure: Change in size during 6 months evaluated by a 0.1 kg precision bascule (SECA 861, SECA, Hamburg, Germany)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline in weight at 6 months
primary_outcome.description: Weight of the children is measured by a 0.1 kg precision bascule (SECA 861, SECA, Hamburg, Germany)

primary_outcome.measure: Change in waist and hip circumference during 6 months evaluated by an anthropometric tape following the ISAK protocol.
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline in waist and hip circumference at 6 months
primary_outcome.description: The waist and hip circumference are measured following the ISAK protocol and measurement technique with an anthropometric tape (Holtain).

primary_outcome.measure: Change in height jump during 6 months evaluated by countermovement jump test
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline in countermovement jump at 6 months
primary_outcome.description: Jump is measured by calculating flight height during countermoving jumps (CMJ) with a Kistler force platform.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in maximum manual pressure during 6 months evaluated by a manual dynamometry.
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline in dynamometry at 6 months
primary_outcome.description: Maximum manual pressure force measured by a manual dynamometry is performed with a Takei-Grip dynamometer (Espana-Romero, 2010) from 5 to 100 kg adjusting the grip to the optimal measure to develop the greatest strength as described for boys and girls

primary_outcome.measure: Change in knee extension isometric strength during 6 months evaluated by a strain gage.
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline in isometric knee extension strength at 6 months
primary_outcome.description: The isometric maximum force of quadriceps extension is evaluated by means of a strain gage anchored firmly to the wall and connected to a specific interface (MuscleLab); the force exerted by the subject for 10 seconds is measured and the maximum peak force is recorded.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in cardiorespiratory fitness during 6 months evaluated by a continuous progressive stress test
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline in cardiorespiratory fitness at 6 months
primary_outcome.description: To assess cardiorespiratory resistance, a continuous progressive test will be carried out until exhaustion, with electrocardiographic control and breath-by-breath gas analysis to measure VO2max by a maximum test with gas analyzer (Oxycon Pro, Jaeger / Viasys, Germany).

primary_outcome.measure: Change in the level of physical activity during 6 months evaluated by accelerometry.
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline in physical activity at 6 months
primary_outcome.description: Accelerometer measures diferent intensities of physical activity during 1 week before and after the training with videogames

primary_outcome.measure: Change in markers of inflammation and metabolic risk during 6 months evaluated by blood analysis
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline in markers of inflammation at 6 months

primary_outcome.measure: Change in systolic blood pressure during 6 months evaluated by sphygmomanometer
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline in systolic blood preasure at 6 months
primary_outcome.description: Systolic blood pressure are measured, in duplicate, at rest with a sphygmomanometer (Omron M3).

primary_outcome.measure: Change in diastolic blood pressure during 6 months evaluated by sphygmomanometer.
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline in diastolic blood pressure at 6 months
primary_outcome.description: Diastolic blood pressure are measured, in duplicate, at rest with a sphygmomanometer (Omron M3).

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in nutrition habits during 6 months evaluated by a questionnaire
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline in nutrition habits at 6 months
secondary_outcome.description: A questionnaire are used, to evaluated the nutritional habits

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in pubertal development during 6 months evaluated by Tanner stages.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline in pubertal development at 6 months
secondary_outcome.description: An experienced physician directly evaluates pubertal development by participants' Tanner stages.

arm_group.description: exergaming exercise: A combination of traditional exercise and exercise through active video games performed 3 days a week for one hour during 7 months. As well, it will be including some session about nutritional advice.
no physical intevention will be provided, but it will be included some sessions on nutritional advice.

intervention.description: An intervention with active video-games to increase physical activity and improve body composition

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- children with obesity and overweight
- children with ages between 9-11 years old
- children in tanner stage I ó II
Exclusion Criteria:
- to take drugs that can affect the measurements
- menarche in girls
- contraindications or pathologies associated with exercise
- regular attendance at extracurricular activities of high energy expenditure
- diet
